The 3 soil tests every site prep project needs (and why skipping them costs you):

1. BEARING CAPACITY TEST
Tells you if soil can support your foundation loads. Skip it = settlement cracks later. Cost: $500-1500. Avoiding it: $50K+ in repairs.

2. COMPACTION TEST  
Verifies fill density meets specs (usually 95% Proctor). We test every 12" lift. One bad layer = the whole pad fails. Cost: $150 per test. Worth every penny.

3. MOISTURE CONTENT
Soil needs optimal moisture to compact properly. Too wet or too dry = poor compaction = future problems. We test throughout the day as conditions change.

Bonus: PERCOLATION TEST for drainage design. Know where water goes BEFORE you grade.

Real cost of proper testing: 1-2% of site work
Real cost of skipping it: 20-40% in fixes

Been doing this [YEARS] years. Test every time.

educational.title: The 3 Phases of Professional Site Grading
educational.hook: Poor grading is the #1 cause of basement flooding - here's how we prevent it
educational.body: Phase 1: Rough grading - we establish major contours and drainage flow away from your building footprint, minimum 2% slope. Phase 2: Fine grading - laser-guided precision to within 1/10th of a foot, ensuring water flows exactly where we want it. Phase 3: Compaction testing - we verify 95% compaction density so your foundation doesn't settle unevenly. See this laser level? It's accurate to 1/16 inch over 300 feet. That precision means no water pooling, no foundation cracks, no drainage nightmares.

educational.title: What Happens During Utility Trenching
educational.hook: We locate every utility before the first scoop - here's our 5-step safety process
educational.body: Step 1: Call 811 and wait for utility marking - legally required, takes 2-3 days. Step 2: Private utility scan for lines not covered by 811 - sprinklers, old septic, private electrical. Step 3: Hand-dig test holes near marked utilities - we verify depth and location. Step 4: Excavate with precision equipment, maintaining proper trench width and depth for code. Step 5: Bedding and backfill with engineered materials, not just dirt. This process prevents the $100K+ disasters you see on the news when someone hits a gas line.
